    Helicobacter pylori Xanthine–Guanine–Hypoxanthine Phosphoribosyltransferase—A Putative Target for Drug Discovery against Gastrointestinal Tract Infections

    • Dianne T. Keough
      Dianne T. Keough
      The School of Chemistry and Molecular Biosciences, The University of Queensland, Brisbane 4072, Queensland, Australia
      More by Dianne T. Keough

    Abstract

    Helicobacter pylori (Hp) is a human pathogen that lives in the gastric mucosa of approximately 50% of the world’s population causing gastritis, peptic ulcers, and gastric cancer. An increase in resistance to current drugs has sparked the search for new Hp drug targets and therapeutics. One target is the disruption of nucleic acid production, which can be achieved by impeding the synthesis of 6-oxopurine nucleoside monophosphates, the precursors of DNA and RNA. These metabolites are synthesized by Hp xanthine–guanine–hypoxanthine phosphoribosyltransferase (XGHPRT). Here, nucleoside phosphonates have been evaluated, which inhibit the activity of this enzyme with Ki values as low as 200 nM. The prodrugs of these compounds arrest the growth of Hp at a concentration of 50 μM in cell-based assays. The kinetic properties of HpXGHPRT have been determined together with its X-ray crystal structure in the absence and presence of 9-[(N-3-phosphonopropyl)-aminomethyl-9-deazahypoxanthine, providing a basis for new antibiotic development.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Gastritis, peptic ulcers, two forms of cancer, gastric mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma, and gastric adenocarcinoma have been shown to be associated with the presence of Helicobacter pylori (Hp) in the gastric mucosa. The finding that Hp is the etiological agent for these diseases was established in 1982 by two Australian scientists, Marshall and Warren,(1) who were subsequently awarded the Nobel Prize for Physiology and Medicine in 2005 for this discovery. Hp is found in the gastric mucosa of at least 50% of the world’s population,(2) though this number is closer to 100% in some countries.(3) Its presence is asymptomatic, and carriers have no prior knowledge of when, or if, life-threatening symptoms could take hold.(4−9) In addition to causing the devastating symptoms of gastritis and peptic ulcers, Hp is the third leading cause of cancer and the most common cause of cancer due to infectious agents, ranking it above papillomavirus and hepatitis B.(10)
    Together with other Gram-negative infections, there has been an alarming increase in multi-drug-resistant (MDR) strains of Hp (where MDR is defined as resistance to ≥ three antibiotics of different classes) in recent years.(4,11) This resistance has been found to be as high as 15–20% and, in some locations, this percentage is higher.(12,13) This led the WHO to include Hp in the list of top 12 pathogens for urgent drug discovery and prompted the drive to find new drug targets and new antibiotics to combat the diseases caused by this organism.(14,15)
    One possible target for innovative therapies to treat Hp infections is the metabolic production of nucleic acids. If this can be interrupted, or significantly slowed, the organism will have a diminished ability to survive. All organisms need to be able to synthesize their own DNA/RNA, and this indicates that they must have a constant supply of precursor nucleoside monophosphates. There are two metabolic routes whereby an organism can obtain these compounds: (i) by the synthesis of the purine ring in a 10-step energetically demanding metabolic pathway (de novo) or (ii) by the transport of purine bases or nucleosides from their host (salvage). Hp has adopted the second of the two strategies with the full complement of genes coding for the de novo pathway being redundant.(16,17)
    Mendz and colleagues undertook the first studies on the purine salvage pathway in Hp(18) and established the role of HpXGHPRT in the synthesis of its purine nucleotides. The fact that Hp requires exogenous purine bases/nucleosides for growth has been documented previously.(19) For microbes, the rate at which they generate AMP and GMP pools has also been found to be the limiting step in their growth(20) and, hence, the need for a fully functional salvage pathway. Figure 1 shows the enzymes available to the bacterium needed to synthesize the nucleoside monophosphates, GMP and IMP, which are then incorporated directly into its DNA and RNA.
    A diagram for the cycling of bases, nucleobases, and nucleotides within Hp is given in Figure 2.
    A central enzyme for the supply of purine nucleoside monophosphates is xanthine–guanine–hypoxanthine phosphoribosyltransferase (XGHPRT) (Figure 2). Thus, it is a candidate for drug intervention of Hp. XGHPRT belongs to a family of enzymes known as 6-oxopurine phosphoribosyltransferases (PRTases). The reaction catalyzed by these enzymes is given in Figure 3.
    It has previously been demonstrated that inhibitors of Plasmodium falciparum (Pf)HGXPRT, Plasmodium vivax (Pv)HGPRT, or Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mt)HGPRT show activity as anti-malarial(21−25) and anti-tuberculosis agents.(26) One class of inhibitors is broadly referred to as “nucleoside phosphonates” as they contain at least one carbon–phosphorus bond, making them stable to enzymatic or chemical hydrolysis. These compounds are designed to mimic either the substrates or products of the catalytic reaction or that of the transition state. The nucleoside phosphonate inhibitors of 6-oxopurine PRTases can be categorized into six groups: the acyclic nucleoside phosphonates (ANPs);(23) the aza-ANPs;(21) the symmetric and asymmetric acyclic nucleoside bis-phosphonates;(27,28) the acyclic immucillin phosphonates (AIPs);(24) the pyrrolidine nucleoside phosphonates (PNPs);(29) and the pyrrolidine nucleoside bis-phosphonates (PNBPs).(22) The scaffolds for these inhibitors are shown in Figure 4.
    Crystal structures of different representatives from these five classes of nucleoside phosphonate inhibitors have been obtained in complex with the 6-oxopurine PRTases from Homo sapiens (Hs), Escherichia coli (Ec), Mt, Pf, and Pv. The Ki values for the inhibitors differ for each of these enzymes. Thus, the crystal structures show not only how they bind in the active site but also provide the explanations for the range of binding constants and offer clues as to how the inhibitor can be tailor-made to fit more tightly in the active site of the 6-oxopurine PRTases from the individual organisms.
    The original design of these inhibitors was based on the successful antiviral drugs including tenofovir, adefovir, and cidofovir, which also contain a nucleobase (either adenine or cytosine) linked by a series of atoms to a phosphonate group.(30,31) To improve the biological activity of those drugs, the negative charges were masked by hydrophobic attachments to increase membrane transport and, thus, their biological activity.(32,33) Such compounds are prodrugs since the masking groups have to be hydrolyzed by intracellular enzymes present in the target cell to release the effective therapeutic.(32,33) This prodrug strategy was thus adopted to convert phosphonate inhibitors of PfHGXPRT and MtHGPRT into compounds that arrest the growth of Pf(21) and Mt in cell-based assays.(26)
    Based on previous studies, HpXGHPRT is suggested as a target enzyme for the development of chemotherapeutics against Hp infections. Herein, recombinant HpXGHPRT has been expressed and purified and its kinetic properties were evaluated. Non-naturally occurring 6-oxopurines were also assayed to determine if they are substrates for the enzyme and if they possess anti-Hp activity in cell assays. Such compounds have the potential to be developed into new therapeutics. In addition, we present the first crystal of HpXGHPRT, which is used to explain substrate specificity and to show how phosphonates newly synthesized in our laboratories inhibit this enzyme. We then demonstrate that the prodrugs of these compounds arrest the growth of Hp in cell-based assays.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Catalytic Properties of the Target Enzyme, HpXGHPRT

    Recombinant hexa-his tag HpXGHPRT was expressed and purified to homogeneity. The kinetic constants of this enzyme for the naturally occurring 6-oxopurine bases and 5-phospho-α-d-ribosyl-1-pyrophosphate (PRib-PP) were determined. These are compared with those for the human 6-oxopurine PRTase as well as three bacterial 6-oxopurine PRTases to assess its relative catalytic efficiency (Table 1).
    Table 1. Kinetic Constants for HpXGHPRT, Human HGPRT, and Three Bacterial 6-Oxopurine PRTases
    enzymekcat (s–1) (G)kcat (s–1) (Hx)kcat (s–1) (X)
    HpXGHPRT7.3 ± 0.24.5 ± 0.42.3 ± 0.3
    HsHGPRT(34)8.2 ± 0.65.2 ± 0.4NSb
    EcXGPRT(35)28.0 ± 0.113.7 ± 1.138.5 ± 0.7
    EcHPRT(36)10.2 ± 0.759.0 ± 3.50.008 ± 0.0001
    MtHGPRT(26)0.62 ± 0.020.55 ± 0.01NSb
    enzymeKm (μM) (G)Km (μM) (Hx)Km (μM) (X)Km (μM) (PRib-PP)
    HpXGHPRT3.1 ± 0.28.4 ± 0.520 ± 227 ± 4a
    HsHGPRT(34)1.9 ± 0.43.4 ± 1.0NS65 ± 5a
    EcXGPRT(35)4.3 ± 0.391 ± 1130.5 ± 2.6139 ± 16a
    EcHPRT(36)294 ± 2012.5 ± 2.425 ± 6.1193 ± 7c
    MtHGPRT(26)4.4 ± 0.48.3 ± 0.7NSb465 ± 15c
    enzymekcat/Km (μM–1 s–1) (G)kcat/Km (μM–1 s–1) (Hx)kcat/Km (μM–1 s–1) (X)kcat/Km (μM–1 s–1) (PRib-PP)
    HpXGHPRT2.30.50.100.3a
    HsHGPRT(34)4.31.5NSb0.13a
    EcXGPRT(35)6.50.151.30.2a
    EcHPRT(36)0.034.70.030.3c
    a

    Guanine as a substrate.

    b

    NS = not a substrate.

    c

    Hx as a substrate.

    In terms of its kcat and Km values for hypoxanthine, guanine, and PRib-PP, HpXGHPRT is more akin to human HGPRT than to the three bacterial enzymes (Table 1). However, HpXGHPRT differs from the human enzyme in that xanthine is not a substrate for the human enzyme, but it is a good substrate for HpXGHPRT with a kcat value only 3 times lower than for guanine and 1.7 times lower for hypoxanthine (Table 1). The Km value of 20 μM demonstrates that it also binds this substrate well, slightly better than EcXGPRT, which has a Km value for xanthine of 30 μM (Table 1).
    The Km value of PRib-PP for HpXGHPRT is also similar to the human enzyme but is 5 times lower than for EcXGPRT, 7 times lower than for EcHPRT, and 17 times lower than for MtHGPRT. Thus, the Hp enzyme has a higher affinity for this substrate than EcXGPRT, EcHPRT, or MtHGPRT (Table 1). The two Ec enzymes have higher kcat values compared with HpXGHPRT for the purine bases. As denoted by their name, EcXGPRT prefers xanthine (19-fold higher) and guanine (4-fold higher), while EcHPRT prefers Hx (16-fold higher). In contrast, these purine bases have much higher Km values for the Ec enzymes, resulting in little difference in catalytic efficiency between these three enzymes (Table 1). MtHGPRT has similar Km values for guanine and Hx as HpXGHPRT, but the major difference lies in their respective kcat values (approximately 10-fold lower for both bases for the Mt enzyme), making MtHGPRT the slowest of these five enzymes but still highly active (Table 1). Thus, HpXGHPRT is an efficient enzyme consistent with its central role in the synthesis of nucleoside monophosphates in vivo. Furthermore, the recombinant enzyme is suitable for screening and testing of compounds that could be developed as drug leads.

    Catalytic Properties of This Enzyme Can Be Used to Arrest the Growth of Hp In Vitro

    The purine base analogues, 6-mercaptopurine and 6-thioguanine, have been shown to possess anti-cancer properties,(37) and they also arrest the growth of Pf in vitro.(34) The mechanism of action of these two anti-cancer agents is via conversion to their toxic metabolites, the corresponding nucleoside monophosphates, by human HGPRT.(37) Thus, HpXGHPRT could play a similar role in Hp.
    6-Thioxanthine is not a substrate for human HGPRT, and it functions as a non-toxic drug in human cells. This purine base requires the introduction of the Ec gpt gene into the cancer cells before cell proliferation can cease or be reduced.(38) It then exerts its anti-cancer activity by the action of the expressed EcXGPRT enzyme, which catalyzes the formation of the corresponding 6-thioxanthine nucleoside monophosphate. GMP synthase converts this nucleoside into the lethal 6-thioguanine monophosphate.(38) This is the principle used in suicide gene therapy, whereby an innocuous compound can be transformed into an active drug.(38)
    The kinetic constants of 6-thioxanthine, 6-thioguanine, and 6-mercaptopurine for HpXGHPRT were determined with a view to ascertain if they were substrates of HpXGHPRT which would convert them into toxic metabolites (Table 2). All three have similar kinetic properties to those of the naturally occurring bases (Table 1). The substitution of the 6-oxo group by a 6-thio group has only a small effect on kcat and Km values for either guanine or xanthine (cf. Table 1). The biggest difference is a 5-fold increase in the Km for 6-mercaptopurine when compared with hypoxanthine. The naturally occurring purine bases, guanine, hypoxanthine, and xanthine, have been shown to be transported into the Hp cells from its host cell (Figure 1), so it is assumed that these three bases would be transported in a similar manner. Table 2 shows that 6-thioguanine and 6-thioxanthine exhibit activity against Hp in cell culture. Thus, purine base analogues have potential as drug leads against Hp. 6-Thioxanthine should exhibit a favorable therapeutic index as it is not a substrate for the human enzyme and it is non-toxic to human cells.
    Table 2. Kinetic Constants of the 6-Thio-Substituted Substrates for HpXGHPRT and Their Activity in Hp Cell Assays
    a

    (−) No growth at 50 μM concentration of the base in the cell culture.

    b

    (+) Some inhibition of growth at 50 μM concentration of the base in the cell culture.

    c

    ND = not determined.

    Inhibitors of This Enzyme and Assessment of Their Prodrugs in Arresting the Growth of Hp in Cell-Based Assays

    Eleven compounds were chosen from our nucleoside phosphonate inventory, and their Ki values were determined for HpXGHPRT (Table 3). All are competitive inhibitors with respect to PRib-PP. The prodrugs of each of these inhibitors were then synthesized to assess their biological activity. The prodrug approach was adopted as the negative charges of the phosphonyl oxygens of these inhibitors severely reduces, or abolishes, their ability to traverse cell membranes.(32,33) Four different masking groups were trialed to determine the prodrug of choice for Hp. The compound number and structure of each inhibitor together with its Ki value and cell-based activity is given in Table 3.
    Table 3. Ki Values of HpXGHPRT Inhibitors and the Biological Activity of Their Prodrugs against Hp in Cell-Based Assays
    a

    A, B, C, and D denote the chemical structure of the masking groups.

    b

    Synthesis in methods, unpublished compound.

    c

    (−) indicates that there is no growth at 50 μM concentration of the compound in the cell culture.

    d

    (+) indicates that there was some inhibition of growth at 50 μM concentration of the compound in the cell culture.

    e

    (+++) indicates that the addition of the inhibitor to the cell culture at 50 μM concentration made no difference to the growth.

    Compound I has one of the lowest Ki values for HpXGHPRT in this series of compounds, and one of its prodrugs, IA, inhibits Hp growth (Table 3). However, the second prodrug of this compound, IB, had no biological effect, even at 50 μM, suggesting that a phenyl group is the preferred option compared with a methyl group for delivery and activation in Hp. Other instances where the substitution of alanine for phenylalanine influences the biological effectiveness of the prodrug in vitro have also been reported.(33,40) It is not known if the differences in biological activity are due to increased transport or to more efficient hydrolysis of the masking group within the cell or whether it is a combination of both.
    Compounds II and III have similar Ki values as I (∼0.2 μM), and their masking group is the same as IA. The prodrug of IIA is slightly more effective in vitro than IIIA. The only difference between II and III is the number of carbon atoms in the linker connecting the hydroxyl group to the nitrogen atom with II having one extra carbon. Though the effect on the anti-bacterial growth is not marked, this extra carbon in the linker affects either transport or hydrolysis in the Hp cells.
    There is little difference in the Ki values between IV and V (0.4 and 1.1 μM), and they have the same masking groups. Therefore, it is not unexpected that the prodrugs, IV-A and V-A, have a similar ability to prevent Hp growth in vivo. Compound VI has a slightly higher Ki value (1.9 μM) than I–V and two different prodrugs of this compound were synthesized (VI-C and VI-D). Surprisingly, the prodrug with 252 masking group “D” has better Hp activity than C. This masking group was originally prepared for use as an anti-malarial drug formulation as it is a mimic of primaquine. However, it works well as a prodrug for Hp.
    Compounds VII–X have Ki values between 2 and 5 μM. With a similar masking group, all possess activity against Hp though VIII-A and X-A are slightly more effective. X-A has good biological activity and its parent compound is a good inhibitor. Its activity against the growth of Hp in vitro could be due to the fact that there is only one phosphonate group and, therefore, only two masking groups have to be hydrolyzed as opposed to four. Furthermore, the attachment of the hydrophobic phenyl group could facilitate transport. This prodrug also possesses excellent IC50 values against Pf and Mt in cell culture (1.5 and 1.1 μM), suggesting that this form of drug and prodrug as a good lead for chemotherapeutic development.
    Compound XI is the guanine analogue of V, but it has a higher Ki value (cf. 32 μM with 1.1 μM) (Table 3). The masking group in both these prodrugs is the same, so the only difference is in the value of the inhibition constant. V-A has good biological activity in vitro but XI-A has no effect, suggesting that the parent compound has to be a good inhibitor of HpXGPRT to be effective in vitro.
    The cytotoxicity in human cells for a number of these compounds has been determined previously. These values range from 100 to >300 μM, higher concentrations than those needed to kill Hp in culture.(21,22,26−29,39,41) This good selectivity index is an indication that these compounds are forerunners for antibiotic development against Hp.

    Subunit Size and Amino Acid Sequence of HpXGHPRT

    A bioinformatic study was performed to assess the similarity and differences in the amino acid sequences between HpXGHPRT and the four 6-oxopurine PRTases (Figure 5).(42,43) The subunit of HpXGHPRT consists of 153 amino acids making it, along with EcXGPRT (152 amino acids), one of the two smallest of these five enzymes (HsHGPRT contains 218 residues, EcHPRT contains 178 residues, and MtHGPRT contains 202 residues) (Figure 5).
    There is little amino acid sequence identity between HpXGHPRT and the other four enzymes with HpXGHPRT having 29% identity with EcXGPRT, 24% identity with human HGPRT, 36% with EcHPRT, and 29% with MtHGPRT. Overall, there are only eight completely conserved amino acid residues (G36, L43, S59, Y60, D92, G94, K121, and P136) (Figure 5). Based on this sequence alignment, six of the eight conserved residues are in the expected binding site of the functional groups of the substrates/products of the reaction, while L43 and P136 do not appear to have a significant role in either catalysis or substrate/product binding.

    Biological Unit of HpXGHPRT in Solution

    On gel filtration in 0.1 M Tris-HCl, 0.01 M MgCl2, pH 7.4 containing 1 mM DTT, HpXGHPRT elutes as a fully active dimer with a molecular mass of 38.6 ± 1.9 kDa. This compares with the calculated molecular mass of 36.9 kDa. It is, therefore, likely that the active biological unit is dimeric. Under identical conditions, EcXGPRT eluted from the same column with a mass of 69.3 ± 2.8 kDa, consistent with the calculated mass of a tetramer (65.6 kDa). MtHGPRT exhibited a mass of 91 ± 3.9 kDa, which is tetrameric (calculated mass of 92 kDa). EcXGPRT has previously been found to elute as an active tetramer on Superose-12 gel filtration(35) while analytical studies(36) and gel filtration of EcHPRT confirm that, in solution, this enzyme is also a tetramer, suggesting that this is its active biological unit. Active human HGPRT also exists as a tetramer in solution.(44) Thus, not only is HpXGHPRT a catalytically efficient member of the 6-oxopurine PRTase family but it is the smallest of these enzymes in its molecular mass in solution.

    Crystal Structure of HpXGHPRT

    In order to explain how inhibitors bind to HpXGHPRT and to provide a framework for rational design, the knowledge of the 3D structure of the enzyme is essential. Two crystal structures of HpXGHPRT have, therefore, been obtained. One is in the absence of added ligand and the second in the presence of 9-[(N-3-phosphonopropyl)-aminomethyl]-9-deazahypoxanthine (compound XII).(24,25) In both cases, the asymmetric unit (ASU) contains a dimer. Data collection, processing, and refinement statistics are given in Table 4.
    Table 4. Data Collection, Processing, and Refinement Statistics for Two Crystal Structures of HpXGHPRT
     no inhibitor(+) compound XII
    Crystal Data

    unit cell angle α, β, γ (deg)90, 96.09, 9090, 96.21, 90
    space groupP21P21
    Diffraction Data
    temperature (K)100100
    resolution range (Å)43.67–1.47 (1.49–1.47)a43.78–1.96 (2.08–1.96)a
    observations389,538 (16,723)3,335,000 (473,183)b
    unique reflections57,196 (2566)24,376 (2370)
    completeness (%)99.0 (89.2)99.5 (96.7)
    Rmergec0.080 (0.592)0.088 (0.592)
    Rpimd0.036 (0.264)0.020 (0.101)

    a

    The values in parentheses are for the outer resolution shell.

    b

    A high redundancy of data was obtained because we were anticipating the need for anomalous phasing of the data. However, the structure was ultimately solved by molecular replacement. There was strong electron density for the side chains of all the amino acids including those that are negatively charged, indicating that no radiation damage occurred during the time of data collection.

    c

    Rmerge = ∑hkl∑i|Ii(hkl) – (I(hkl))|/∑hkl∑iIi(hkl).

    d

    Rp.i.m. = ∑hkl[1/[N(hkl) – 1]]1/2∑i|Ii(hkl) – (I(hkl))|/∑hkl∑iIi(hkl), where Ii(hkl) is the observed intensity and is the average intensity obtained from multiple observations of symmetry-related reflections.

    e

    Clashscore is defined as the number of bad overlaps ≥0.4 Å per thousand atoms.

    Subunit 3D Structure of HpXGHPRT

    The subunit structure of HpXGHPRT in the absence of added ligand is shown in Figure 6. The electron density map of this structure shows two tetrahedral shapes which we have ascribed to sulfate ions arising from the crystallization solution. This assignment was confirmed by an anomalous difference map showing a strong signal for sulfur in chain B at the 5′-phosphate binding pocket. There is also a weaker signal in the density in the predicted PPi binding site for sulfur but, as this is just above the background, it was less conclusive. The location of the eight completely conserved amino acids in the five 6-oxopurine PRTases in the subunit structure are also shown together with the two acidic amino acids predicted to be involved with binding a divalent metal ion.

    Comparison of the Subunit Structure of HpXGHPRT with the Human and Three Other Bacterial Enzymes

    The secondary structure of Hp consists of four α-helices and four β-sheets and has a core structure that is similar to four other 6-oxopurine PRTases (Figure 7). The most significant structural differences between these five enzymes occur at the C-terminus (residues 122–153 in HpXGHPRT): HsHGPRT, EcHPRT, and MtHGPRT. All have two β-sheets at their C-terminal, while for EcXGPRT, the C-terminus reaches the active site of the adjoining subunit. HpXGHPRT, in contrast, has an α-helix motif of 11 amino acids at the C-terminus.

    Quaternary Crystal Structure of HpXGHPRT

    The dimeric structure of HpXGHPRT is shown in Figure 8. The two sulfate ions are located where the phosphate groups of the two products of the reaction (Figure 3), that is, the 5′-phosphate group of XMP/GMP/IMP and pyrophosphate, are bound.

    Long Flexible Loop

    S59–71I in the amino acid sequence of HpXGHPRT corresponds to 105S–I117 in the human HGPRT amino acid sequence (Figure 5). This region of the human HGPRT structure is called the “long flexible loop”, which closes over the active site when the transition-state analogues are bound.(46) This flexible loop is resolved and visible in one of the subunits (subunit A) of the HpXGHPRT structure (Figure 8) but is disordered in subunit B. Thus, this structure represents two slightly different states, which are either prior to, or just after, the catalytic reaction.

    Two Phosphate Binding Sites

    One of the sulfate ions binds in the predicted 5′-phosphate binding site and the bonding pattern that the sulfonyl oxygens make with main chain and side chain amino acids as well as water molecules is shown in Figure 9A. The electron density for the sulfate group is unequivocal (Figure 9A). Thus, the sulfonyl group is firmly anchored in place by a stretch of amino acids, 92-DSGNS-96. D92 and G94 are two of the completely conserved residues across these five 6-oxopurine PRTases (Figures 5 and 6). The second sulfate ion is found in that area of the enzyme that is predicted to bind pyrophosphate and includes R34 and G35 (Figures 5 and 9B). The “RG” motif is highly conserved across 6-oxopurine PRTases, though in the human and Mt enzymes, arginine is replaced by the similarly charged lysine. R34 helps to keep a stable dimeric structure by formation of a bond between the NH1 atom of its side chain and the carbonyl of L49 in the adjoining subunit. Once again, the electron density for the sulfate ion and nearby waters is unequivocal (Figure 9B). Figure 9C shows that water molecules bridge the two sulfate ions located in the active site. This is the only known structure where the 5′-phosphate binding site and a phosphate mimic in the pyrophosphate binding site are occupied.

    Crystal Structure of HpXGHPRT in Complex with 9-[(N-3-Phosphonopropyl)-aminomethyl]-9-deazahypoxanthine (Compound XII)

    Diffracting crystals were obtained in the presence of [(N-3-phosphonopropyl)-aminomethyl]-9-deazahypoxanthine, which is one of two compounds known as AIPs.(24) These compounds are partial mimics of the transition-state analogues and were designed and synthesized by Schramm and his colleagues.(24) They contain 9-deazahypoxathine as the purine base as well as a positively charged nitrogen in the linker connecting this base to a phosphonate group (Figure 10A,B). The replacement of the N9 atom by a carbon atom decreases the pKa of the N7 atom in the purine ring from 8.5 to 2.3(46,47) and, thus, this atom is protonated under physiological conditions. This protonation was designed so that a hydrogen bond could form between the carboxylate of the highly conserved aspartic acid residue (D92 in HpXGHPRT; Figure 5) and N7 of the purine base, reflecting the prediction of the transition state. Therefore, substitution of the naturally occurring purine base by the deaza base could assist in tighter binding of the inhibitor. 9-Deazaguanine is a competitive inhibitor with guanine for HpXGHPRT having a Ki value of 3.0 ± 0.2 μM, which is similar to the Km for guanine (3.1 μM; Table 1). It is likely, therefore, that 9-deazahypoxanthine would bind in the same location in the active site as the naturally occurring base.
    The positively charged nitrogen in the linker (XII and XIII) mimics that of the oxygen in the chemical structure of the transition state during the catalytic reaction (Figure 10C). Its primary role appears to be in positioning a pyrophosphate group in the active site.
    There is only one published crystal structure of a 6-oxopurine PRTase in complex with an AIP. This is PfHGXPRT in complex with XIII.(24) This complex also contains one pyrophosphate molecule and one magnesium ion per subunit.
    Compound XII is a competitive inhibitor of PfHGXPRT and HsHGPRT and is highly selective for the Pf enzyme.(24) The Ki values of XII for HsHGPRT and PfHGXPRT are 4940 and 11 nM, respectively. The Ki value of XII for HpXGHPRT is 2400 ± 0.4 nM, a value closer to that of the human enzyme. In comparison, the Ki values of XIII for HsHGPRT and PfHGXPRT are much lower, being 385 and 0.65 nM, respectively, suggesting that the addition of the −CH2OH group plays a significant role in determining the Ki value.
    Figure 11A shows the Connolly surface of XII and sulfate bound in the active site of HpXGHPRT (subunit A). XII was not observed in subunit B and just two sulfate ions were found in this subunit. The specific interactions that XII forms when bound in the active site of HpXGHPRT are shown in Figure 11B.
    In this structure, the side-chain atom of D92 has not moved to form a hydrogen bond with the N7 atom of the purine ring as occurs when compound XIII (together with pyrophosphate and a magnesium ion) or the transition-state analogue (together with pyrophosphate and two magnesium ions) bind to either human HGPRT or PfHGXPRT (distance is 2.8 Å in both those cases). Further, the NZ atom of the invariant lysine residue, K121, is far away to form a hydrogen bond with the 6-oxo group of 9-deazahypoxanthine.

    Positively Charged Nitrogen in a Linker

    Figure 12A shows the Connolly surface of PfHGXPRT in complex with XIII and shows that the large flexible loop is firmly closed over the active site and the ligand is “buried” in the active site.(24) The HpXGHPRT·XII complex has been superimposed onto this complex to compare their modes of binding in an attempt to provide a rationale for the range of inhibition constants. Figure 12B,C shows the interactions that the two ligands make in the active sites of their respective enzymes.
    In the HpXGHPRT·XII complex, the positively charged nitrogen is linked, via two bridging waters, to two of the oxygens of the sulfate group located in the pyrophosphate binding site. One of these water molecules is then linked to the OD1 atom of the conserved acidic residue, E89 (Figure 12A,B). The location of this sulfate ion mimics that of the second phosphate group of pyrophosphate, which is found in the active site of the PfHGXPRT·XIII complex (Figure 12A,C).(24) In the HpXGHPRT·XII structure, the second water molecule fulfills the role of one of the oxygen atoms of the pyrophosphate group in the PfHGXPRT·XIII complex (cf. Figure 12B,C).
    Thus, the role of the positively charged nitrogen atom in both these structures is to contribute to holding the sulfate ion (or a phosphate ion which can substitute for sulfate) or PPi (PfHGXPRT). It also helps in positioning the side chain of the conserved acidic residue (cf. Figure 12B,C). When the transition-state analogue, ImmHp, binds to PfHGXPRT (PDB code: 1CJB)(47) together with pyrophosphate and two magnesium ions, a similar role is attributed to the positively charged atom as it is also linked to the phosphoryl oxygens of pyrophosphate.
    Thus, the HpXGHPRT·XII complex is a partial reflection of the transition state in catalysis of this enzyme. Attempts to crystallize with pyrophosphate included in the active site together with compound XII were unsuccessful. This is attributed to the fact that this binding site may have been already occupied by sulfate and pyrophosphate was unable to displace it.

    Positioning of the Purine Ring

    In subunit B of the HpXGHPRT structure in the absence or presence of a ligand, the side chain of W138 forms a π-stacking arrangement with the side chain of a histidine residue (Figure 13). This residue is two residues distal to the beginning of the authentic amino acid sequence (HYSY) and is the fifth histidine residue at the N-terminus in the added hexa-his tag. In subunit A, in the absence of the inhibitor, the same histidine residue has not formed this packing arrangement and is freely rotating. Hence, its side chain is not visible and has been modeled in as alanine (Figure 13). The side chain of W138 is then not restricted and freely rotates (Figure 13). The B-factor for this side chain is 62 Å2 indicative of its flexibility. In contrast, the B-factor in chain A is 22 Å2 as it is firmly clamped in its position.
    In all the 6-oxopurine PRTases, the purine base of the substrate or inhibitor is also “locked” into position by a π-stacking arrangement with the side chain of an aromatic amino acid. In EcXGPRT, this amino acid residue is tryptophan, while in HsHGPRT,(46) EcHPRT,(36) and MtHGPRT,(26) it is phenylalanine (Figure 5). The aromatic amino acid is located on a flexible loop where it is freely rotatable and it only moves over the active site when a purine base, either free as in the PfHGXPRT·Hx·PPi·Mg2+ complex (PDB code: 3OZF)(24) or as the nucleoside monophosphate or a phosphonate inhibitor, enters the active site of these enzymes.(22,48)

    Xanthine Is a Substrate for HpXGHPRT

    Xanthine binds to HpXGHPRT and EcXGPRT with similar Km values, 20 and 30 μM, respectively (Table 1). However, this purine base is not a substrate for human HGPRT. In the EcXGPRT·GMP complex, the exocyclic amino group forms two hydrogen bonds, one with a bridging water to the OD1 atoms of E136 and D140 and the second to the carbonyl of I135. When xanthine binds, the exocyclic oxygen atom forms a bond with the water molecule, but it is not possible to make a bond with the carbonyl of I135, so the position of the base shifts slightly to avoid repulsion. In the HpXGHPRT·XII complex, there is only a proton in the 2-position of the purine ring. In this structure, the side chain of E144 points toward the active site. This makes the distance between C2 and the OD oxygen of E144, 3.4 Å. Thus, there is room to accommodate an exocyclic oxo group in this area of the active site and accounts for the fact that xanthine is a good substrate for this enzyme.
    The Cα backbone of human HGPRT adopts a different configuration in this region (cf. Figure 14A,B). The exocyclic amino group of, the inhibitor, compound I (Table 3) forms a hydrogen bond with the carbonyl of D193. Thus, if xanthine tried to bind to this enzyme, repulsion would exist between the exocyclic oxygen atom and the carbonyl oxygen of D193 with the result that this purine base cannot bind to the human enzyme.

    Binding Site for a Divalent Metal Ion

    In 6-oxopurine PRTases, there are two highly conserved acidic amino acid residues (Figure 5). These are D88 and E89 in HpXGHPRT (Figure 15). They occupy a similar location in subunits A and B in both of the two HpXGHPRT structures. These two corresponding amino acid residues in the 6-oxopurine PRTase structures have been found to be directly coordinated to magnesium in the absence of a ligand(36) or in the presence of a phosphonate inhibitor.(22) When the transition-state analogues are bound, they are indirectly coordinated to a magnesium ion via a hydrogen bond to the iminoribitol hydroxyl groups.(46,47) In contrast, there is no electron density found in the two high-resolution structures of HpXGHPRT to show the presence of metal ion within the coordination distance of the side chains of these two residues and, instead, they are turned toward each other and, via water molecules, to the sulfonyl oxygens of the sulfate group located in the binding pocket of the β-phosphate pocket and the carbonyl of V82. This residue is conserved as either valine or leucine in this group of 6-oxopurine PRTases (Figure 5).

    Role of K121

    K121 in HpXGHPRT is highly conserved across 6-oxopurine PRTases (Figure 5). It has been proposed that its role is to confer the specificity for this class of enzymes by forming a hydrogen bond between the NZ atom and the exocyclic oxo group. Thus, 6-oxopurine phosphoribosyltransferases are unable to use adenine as a substrate because repulsion would occur with the exocyclic amino group.
    In the HpXGHPRT complex, the NZ atom of K121, which is located on a flexible loop, is 5.9 Å away from the 6-oxo atom of the purine ring and, consequently, unable to form a bond with the 6-oxo group (Figure 11). Instead, the 6-oxo exocyclic group forms a hydrogen bond with a bridging water molecule and, via this molecule, to the backbone carbonyl of the conserved proline residue, P136 (Figure 16). The NZ atom of K121 forms a hydrogen bond with a water molecule, which is then linked to the carbonyl backbone oxygen of A137. This network appears to be the basis for the 6-oxopurine specificity of the Hp enzyme. HpXGHPRT retains its specificity, though for the 6-oxo group, and adenine is not a substrate. HpXGHPRT (360 nM, final concentration) was added to the cuvette containing 0.1 M Tris-HCl, 0.01 M MgCl2, pH 7.4, 114 μM adenine, and 550 μM PRib-PP at 25 °C and the reaction followed spectrophotometrically at 255 nm for 600 s. The concentration of adenine is 16 times that of the Km value for guanine, 25 times higher than for Hx, and 50 times higher than for xanthine (Table 1) and the enzyme concentration is 10 times than when guanine was used as a substrate. However, there was no change in absorbance (<0.001) over this time period, so the enzyme is unable to convert adenine to AMP. Thus, the method adopted by HpXGHPRT to bind the 6-oxopurine base has not broadened its specificity for the purine base, and it retains its specificity for an exocyclic 6-oxo group.
    EcXGPRT also appears to adopt a modified network of bonds and is maybe less reliant that the other 6-oxopurine PRTases on the ubiquitous lysine residue.(45) The distance between the 6-oxo group and the NZ atom is 3.6 Å when GMP is bound, but this is 3.2 Å in the presence of the inhibitor, (S)-3-(guanin-9-yl)pyrrolidine-N-ylacetylphosphonic acid (Figure 14). This bacterial enzyme may place greater reliance on the hydrogen bond with the amide of I135.(45) This residue is highly conserved (Figure 5) and completely conserved between EcXGPRT and HpXGHPRT, but it does not perform the same role in the Hp enzyme as it is located too far away from the 6-oxogroup. Thus, though the proline amino acid residue is completely conserved across this group of the 6-oxopurine PRTases, it is only in the HpXGHPRT enzyme that it appears to have an important role to play in the enzyme function.

    Derivative of Compound XII

    A derivative of XII was synthesized with the aim of positioning a second phosphonate group in the pyrophosphate binding pocket. The chemical structure of this compound (XIV) is given in Figure 17.
    This molecule inhibited HpXGHPRT with a Ki of 4 ± 0.7 μM. Thus, though this modification did not result in the desired decrease in the inhibition constant, compound XIV does not inhibit human HGPRT, even at a concentration of 46 μM in the assay. Thus, like xanthine and its derivatives, it is highly selective for HpXGHPRT. This result suggests possibilities for the design of inhibitors totally specific for the bacterial enzyme. Thus, like 6-thioxanthine, this compound can constitute a lead molecule for therapeutics.

    Possible Binding Modes of Compounds I and III to HpXGHPRT

    In an attempt to explain the lower Ki values of compounds I and III compared with compound XII, two known structural complexes were superimposed onto that of the HpXGHPRT·XIII complex. These are the human HGPRT·I complex (PDB code: 5HIA)(22) and the MtHGPRT·III complex (PDB code: 4RHX)(26) (Figure 18).
    Both I and III contain a second phosphonate group covalently attached to a nitrogen atom in the pyrrolidine ring (Figure 18A) or in the acyclic linker (Figure 18B) (Table 3). In the human HGPRT·I complex, this phosphonate group reaches further into the putative pyrophosphate binding site than that of the phosphonate group in the MtHGPRT·III complex. In both cases, the phosphonyl oxygens would be expected to form additional interactions in the active site compared with compound XII, thus contributing to the decrease in the Ki values (2.4 μM for XII cf. 0.2 μM for I and 0.3 μM for III; Table 3). These superimpositions are possible binding modes to show that these two compounds bind in the active site of HpXGHPRT, but other variations are possible given the flexible nature of the active site of the enzyme and the compounds themselves. Nonetheless, the superposition provides a basis for proposing future chemical modifications to increase the affinity.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    HpXGHPRT is one of the smallest and most compact of 6-oxopurine PRTases with a subunit mass of 17,327 Da and exists, in solution, as an active dimer. It is catalytically efficient, using all the three naturally occurring purine bases with kcat/Km values of 2.3, 0.5, and 0.1 μM–1 s–1 for guanine, hypoxanthine, and xanthine, respectively. These kinetic properties suggest that the nucleoside phosphonates, a class of inhibitors of other 6-oxopurine PRTases, may also inhibit HpXGHPRT activity. All 12 such compounds investigated here were found to inhibit this enzyme with the lowest Ki value being 200 nM. Prodrugs, designed to increase membrane transport of these inhibitors, arrested the growth of Hp in cell-based assays. The catalytic properties of HpXGHPRT can also be used to convert foreign substrates into toxic metabolites, which are shown to be effective in vitro against Hp growth. Thus, the enzymatic properties of HpXGHPRT can be used in two ways to prevent the growth of Hp. The inhibitors and the substrate analogue have low to negligible toxicity in human cells. The first crystal structures of HpXGHPRT have been obtained. These structures provide clues for chemical modifications to the inhibitors to increase their potency. The innovative therapeutics described here are specific for HpXGPRT as they are based on the chemical structure of its substrates/products. As such, it is unlikely that they could potently bind to other proteins. The enzymological properties of HpXGHPRT combined with its 3D structure thus provide a platform for the design of new chemotherapeutics aimed at the treatment of Hp infections.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Expression and Purification of HpXGHPRT

    Hexa-his tag HpXGHPRT was expressed and purified to homogeneity as for human hexa-his tag HGPRT.(21) The purified enzyme was stored at −80 °C in 0.1 M Tris-HCl, 0.1 M MgCl2, pH 7.4, containing 1 mM DTT, and 400 μM PRib-PP. The concentration of protein was calculated using an A1cm1% of 1.38 M–1 cm–1 and a subunit molecular mass of 18,481.1 Da.

    Determination of Kinetic Constants

    The kinetic constants, kcat and Km, were measured using a continuous spectrophotometric assay in 0.1 M Tris-HCl, 0.01 M MgCl2, pH 7.4, and 25 °C. The reaction was initiated by the addition of an aliquot of enzyme to the cuvette containing the assay buffer and the two substrates, the purine base and PRib-PP. The reaction was followed for 60 s over the absorbance range of 0–0.05 a.u. The reaction for each base was followed at these wavelengths: guanine (257.5 nm), hypoxanthine (245 nm), xanthine (255 nm), 6-mercaptopurine (300 nm), 6-thioguanine (355 nm), 6-thioxanthine (355 nm), and adenine (255 nm). The Δε values for the different bases are guanine (5816.5 M–1 cm–1), hypoxanthine (2439 M–1 cm–1), xanthine (4685 M–1 cm–1), 6-mercaptopurine (3284 M–1 cm–1), 6-thioguanine (4310 M–1 cm–1), 6-thioxanthine (3740 M–1 cm–1), and adenine (3300 M–1 cm–1).(34) The Km values for the bases were measured under saturating conditions of PRib-PP (580 μM), and the Km values for PRib-PP under saturating conditions of guanine, 64 μM. All experiments were performed as technical replicates in triplicate. The kinetic constants were calculated using GraphPad Prism.

    Determination of Ki Values

    The two substrates and the inhibitor were incubated in the assay buffer, 0.1 M Tris-HCl, 0.01 M MgCl2, pH 7.4, at 25 °C, and the reaction initiated by the addition of an aliquot of enzyme. Km(app) was first calculated at different concentrations of inhibitor using the equation, vo = Vmax·[S]o/Km(app) + [S]o. The concentration of inhibitor was then chosen so that the Km(app) was at least 5 times the concentration of the variable substrate. The Ki values were determined at a constant concentration of guanine (64 μM) and a range of concentrations of PRib-PP (10–1200 μM). The range of inhibitor concentrations varied from 1 to 140 μM, depending on the degree of inhibition by that particular inhibitor. Initial velocity (vo) was determined at the substrate saturation concentration. All experiments were performed as technical replicates in triplicate. For compound XII, the Ki was calculated using the Morrison equation(50) as for the inhibition of the human and Pf 6-oxopurine PRTases by this compound.(24)

    Gel Filtration

    Gel filtration was performed using size exclusion chromatography coupled to multi-angle light scattering (SEC–MALS) and with a G-75 Sephadex column equilibrated in 0.1 M Tris-HCl, 0.01 M MgCl2, pH 7.4 containing 1 mM DTT.

    Crystallization and Structure Determination

    The concentration of enzyme used to obtain highly diffracting crystals was 0.22 mM in terms of subunits (i.e., 4 mg mL–1). To obtain crystals for the HpXGHPRT·XII complex, the enzyme was incubated with or without XII (5.75 mM) on ice for 5 min prior to setting up the crystal trays. The crystallization conditions were found by using the crystallization screening plates prepared by the Mosquito protein crystallization robot with 100 nL of the screening condition and 100 nL of protein. The crystallization screen was JCSG Plus from Molecular Dimensions. The crystallization conditions are 0.1 M bis–Tris-propane, pH 5.5, 0.2 M (NH4)2SO4, and 25% PEG3350. HpXGHPRT crystals, in the presence and absence of XII, were obtained using the hanging drop method with 2 μL of enzyme and 2 μL of well solution. The trays were incubated at 18 °C and crystals became visible after 14 days. The cryoprotectant was 10% glycerol in the well solution to which was added compound XII to afford a final concentration of 1 mM. Crystals were cryocooled in liquid nitrogen for transport to the Australian Synchrotron where they were robotically placed in a cryostream (100 K). X-ray data were collected remotely at the MX2 beamline.(51) All data sets were processed with XDS.(52)
    The structure of the HpHGXPRT·XII complex was determined by molecular replacement with Auto-Rickshaw(53,54) with MoRDa(55) identifying and using the PDB accession code, 5BQP, Sulfolobus solfataricus HGXPRT as a template model. The template model indicated about 27% sequence identity against the target molecule. The resulting model was subjected to rigid body, positional and B-factor refinement in CNS(56) and continued to refine with REFMAC5(57) resulting in R/Rfree to 45.6/49.5%. At this stage, density modification was carried out with the model phase in PIRATE(58) and the improved phases were used for model building in ARP/wARP.(59) The initial model contained 246 out of total 306 residues and of which 226 residues were correctly fitted in the electron density and refinement of the model resulted in R/Rfree to 27.4/31.4%. Subsequent refinement and manual model building were performed with PHENIX 1.8(60) and COOT 0.8,(61) respectively. The liganded structure was solved by MR using the program PHASER(62) and the unliganded structure of HpXGHPRT as a starting model within PHENIX 1.8(60) and refinement and model building were carried out as described above. The data collection, processing, and refinement statistics for all of the data sets are presented in Table 4.

    Hp In Vitro Assays

    Stock solutions of the prodrug (50 mM) were prepared in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). These solutions were then diluted further to give a final concentration of 1 mM in DMSO. Aqueous stock solutions of the purine bases (approx. 2 mM) were also diluted to give a final concentration of 1 mM.
    The Hp strain 26695 was cultivated under microaerobic conditions (6% O2, 6% CO2, and 88% N2) at 37 °C in brain heart infusion (BHI) broth supplemented with 10% (v/v) fetal calf serum and 0.2% (v/v) Skirrow’s supplement.(63) Cell suspensions were diluted with the BHI media to give a cell density of 106 bacteria/mL.
    Horse blood agar (950 μL), containing 8% (v/v) horse blood and 0.2% (v/v) Skirrow’s supplement,(64) were added into each well. The compounds (50 μL) or DMSO (50 μL) was added into each well. DMSO alone was added to determine that any decrease in cell growth was not due to DMSO itself. The final concentration of DMSO was 5%. To each well, 10 μL of the cell suspension was then added. The plates were then incubated at 37 °C for three days in microaerobic condition (6% O2, 6% CO2, and 88% N2). Cell growth was then observed.

    Bioinformatic Analysis

    The protein sequences for HpXGHPRT, EcXGPRT, HsHGPRT, EcHPRT, and MtHGPRT were obtained from UniProtKB.(43) ClustalW2 was used to perform the sequence alignments of the enzyme.(42)

    Synthesis of the Inhibitors and Their Prodrugs

    Except for the three prodrugs, II-A, VI-C, and VI-D (synthesis described in the paragraphs below), the inhibitors and their prodrugs (listed below) were synthesized as described previously. They were all stored at 5 °C, under which conditions, they are stable for >10 years. These compounds are >95% pure as assessed by liquid chromatography/mass spectrometry (LC/MS). [3R,4R]-4-Guanin-9-yl-3-((S)-2-hydroxy-2-phosphonoethyl)oxy-1-N-(phosphonopropionyl)pyrrolidine (I, Table 3(22)); tetra-(l-phenylalanine ethyl ester) prodrug of [3R,4R]-4-guanin-9-yl-3-((S)-2-hydroxy-2-phosphonoethyl)oxy-1-N-(phosphonopropionyl)pyrrolidine (I-A, Table 3(22)); tetra-(l-alanine ethyl ester) prodrug of [3R,4R]-4-guanin-9-yl-3-((S)-2-hydroxy-2-phosphonoethyl)oxy-1-N-(phosphonopropionyl)pyrrolidine (I-B, Table 3(22)); (2-((2-(guanin-9-yl)ethyl)(2-((2-hydroxypropyl)(2-phosphonoethyl)amino)ethyl)amino)ethyl)phosphonic acid (II, Table 3(26)); (2-((2-(guanin-9-yl)ethyl)(2-((2-hydroxyethyl)(2-phosphonoethyl)amino)ethyl)amino)ethyl)phosphonic acid (III, Table 3(26)); tetra-(l-phenylalanine ethyl ester) prodrug of (2-((2-(guanin-9-yl)ethyl)(2-((2-hydroxyethyl)(2-phosphonoethyl)amino)ethyl)-amino)ethyl)phosphonic acid (III-A, Table 3(26)); sodium salt of [3-(guanine-9-yl)-2-((2-phosphonoethoxy)methyl)propoxy]methyl phosphonic acid (IV, Table 3(27)); tetra-(l-phenylalanine ethyl ester) prodrug of [3-(guanine-9-yl)-2-((2-phosphonoethoxy)methyl)propoxy]methyl-phosphonic acid (IV-A, Table 3(27)); 9-[(N-phosphonoethyl-N-phosphonoethoxyethyl)-2-aminoethyl]hypoxanthine (V, Table 3(21)); tetra-(l-phenylalanine ethyl ester) prodrug of 9-[(N-phosphonoethyl-N-phosphonoethoxyethyl)-2-aminoethyl]hypoxanthine (V-A, Table 3(21)); diisopropyl (S)-((2-(guanin-9-yl)pyrrolidine-1-yl)-2-oxoethyl)phosphonate (VI, Table 3(29)); sodium salt of [(2-(guanine-9-yl)propane-1,3-diyl)bis(oxy)]bis(ethane-2,1-diyl) diphosphonic acid (VII, Table 3(28)); tetra-(l-phenylalanine ethyl ester) prodrug of [(2-(guanine-9-yl)propane-1,3-diyl)bis(oxy)]bis(ethane-2,1-diyl)diphosphonic acid (VII-A, Table 3(28)); [(2-[(guanin-yl)methyl]propane-1,3-diyl)bis(oxy)]bis(methylene) diphosphonic acid (VIII, Table 3(21)); tetra-(l-phenylalanine ethyl ester) prodrug of [(2-[(guanin-9-yl)methyl]propane-1,3-diyl)bis(oxy)]bis(methylene) diphosphonic acid (V-IIIA, Table 3(21)); sodium salt of [3-(8-bromoguanine-9-yl)-2-((2-phosphonoethoxy)methyl)propoxy]methyl) phosphonic acid (IX, Table 3(27)); tetra-(l-phenylalanine ethyl ester) prodrug of [3-(8-bromoguanine-9-yl)-2-((2-phosphonoethoxy)methyl)propoxy]methyl phosphonic acid (IX-A, Table 3(27)); (2-((2-(benzyloxy)ethyl)(2-(guanin-9-yl)ethyl)amino)ethyl)phosphonate (X, Table 3(39)); bis-(l-phenylalanine isopropyl ester) prodrug of (2-((2-(benzyloxy)ethyl)(2-(guanin-9-yl)ethyl)amino)ethyl)phosphonate (X-A, Table 3(39)); 9-[(N-phosphonoethyl-N-phosphonoethoxyethyl)-2-aminoethyl]guanine (XI, Table 3(21)); tetra-(l-phenylalanine ethyl ester) prodrug of 9-[(N-phosphonoethyl-N-phosphonoethoxyethyl)-2-aminoethyl]guanine (XI-A, Table 3(21)); 9-[(N-3-phosphonopropyl)-aminomethyl]-9-deazahypoxanthine (XII, Figure 10(24)); and 9-[(N,N-(bis-3-phosphonopropyl))-aminomethyl]-9-deazahypoxanthine (XIV, Figure 17(49)) were prepared previously as described previously (Table 3).

    Synthesis of Tetra-(l-phenylalanine ethyl ester) Prodrug of (2-((2-(Guanin-9-yl)ethyl)(2-((2-hydroxypropyl)(2-phosphonoethyl)amino)ethyl)amino)ethyl)phosphonic Acid (II-A)

    A mixture of diethyl (2-((2-(guanin-9-yl)ethyl)(2-((2-hydroxypropyl)(2-phosphonoethyl)amino)ethyl)amino)ethyl)phosphonate,(29) (0.5 mmol), dry pyridine (8 mL), and BrSiMe3 (1 mL) was stirred overnight at room temperature under argon. After evaporation and co-distillation with pyridine (2 × 5 mL) under an argon atmosphere, the residue was dissolved in dry pyridine (10 mL) and ethyl (l)-phenylalanine hydrochloride (1.75 g, 7.1 mmol) and triethylamine (3.1 mL) were added. The mixture was heated to 70 °C under an argon atmosphere and then a solution of aldrithiol (2.31 g, 10.5 mmol) and triphenylphosphine (2.75 g, 10.5 mmol) in dry pyridine (8 mL) was added. The reaction mixture was heated at 70 °C for 3 days, the solvent was evaporated, and the residue co-evaporated with toluene (2 × 10 mL) and purified by column chromatography on silica gel (gradient CHCl3–MeOH). The crude product further purified by preparative high-performance LC (HPLC). The phosphoramidate prodrug was obtained as foam, yield 34%. 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d6): 1.13 (m, 12H, Et); 1.63 (m, 4H, CH2–P); 2.61 (m, 8H) and 2.76 (m, 4H, CH2–N); 2.95 (m, 10H, CH2Ph and CH2); 3.48 (m, 2H, H-11′); 4.04 (m, 14H, Et, CHNH and H-1′); 4.23 (m, 4H, NH); 5.91 (s, 1H, OH); 6.21 (s, 2H, NH2); 7.24 (m, 20H, Ar); 7.60 (s, 1H, H-8); 10.31 (s, 1H, NH). 13C NMR (126 MHz, DMSO-d6): 13.47 (m, 4C, Et); 26.43 (d, 2C, JP,C = 111.5, C–P); 43.71 (C-1′); 47.23; 50.24, 50.36 (2C), 50.75, 52.27 and 53.39 (C–N); 53.88 (m, 4C, NHCH); 58.82 (C–OH); 60.00 (m, 4C, Et); 116.57 (C-5); 126.08 (m, 4C, Ar); 127.72 (m, 8C, Ar); 128.92 (m, 8C, Ar); 136.90 (m, 4C, Ar); 136.96 (C-8); 150.91 (C-4); 153.27 (C-2); 156.45 (C-6); 172.53 m, 4C (CO). MS (ESI): m/z = 1212 [M + H]+. This compound is >95% pure as assessed by LC/MS.

    Synthesis of Bis-(2-pivaloylthioethyl) Diamide Prodrug of Diisopropyl (S)-((2-(Guanin-9-yl)pyrrolidine-1-yl)-2-oxoethyl)phosphonate (VI-C)

    2-Chloro-5,5-dimethyl-1,3,2-dioxaphosphorinane 2-oxide (0.6 g, 3.25 mmol) was added to the mixture of triethylammonium salt of (S)-3-(guanin-9-yl)-pyrrolidine-N-ylacetylphosphonic acid (synthesized according to the published procedure(22)) (0.29 g, 0.65 mmol), trioctylamine (0.45 g, 1.3 mmol), and 2-pivaloylthioethanol (0.32 g, 1.96 mmol) in pyridine (10 mL). The reaction was stirred overnight under an argon atmosphere at rt. The reaction mixture was concentrated in vacuo, dissolved in chloroform (20 mL), and washed with a saturated solution of NaHCO3 (20 mL) and 1% citric acid (20 mL). The organic phase was dried over Na2SO4 and the desired product was obtained by column chromatography on silica gel using a linear gradient of ethanol in chloroform in 70% yield (0.29 g, 0.46 mmol) in the form of a white amorphous solid. The product was lyophilized from dioxane. According to NMR, an ∼ 1:1 mixture of A and B rotamers was obtained.
    1H NMR (499.8 MHz, CD3OD, 25 °C): 1.209, 1.211, 1.226, 1.231 (4 × s, 4 × 9H, (CH3)3C-A,B); 2.48 (m, 1H, H-4′b-B); 2.51–2.59 (m, 3H, H-4′a-B, H-4′-A); 3.14–3.20 (m, 8H, SCH2CH2O-A,B); 3.21–3.28 (m, 4H, CH2P-A,B); 3.63 (bm, 1H, H-5′b-B); 3.76 (bm, 1H, H-5′a-B); 3.85 (bm, 1H, H-5′b-A); 3.92 (bdd, 1H, Jgem = 12.7, J2′b,3′ = 5.0, H-2′b-A); 3.98 (bm, 1H, H-2′a-A); 4.00 (bm, 1H, H-5′a-A); 4.09 (dd, 1H, Jgem = 10.8, J2′b,3′ = 6.0, H-2′b-B); 4.15–4.23 (m, 9H, H-2′a-B, SCH2CH2O-A,B); 5.05 (m, 1H, H-3′-A); 5.11 (m, 1H, H-3′-B); 7.78, 7.83 (2 × s, 2 × 1H, H-8-A,B).
    13C NMR (125.7 MHz, CD3OD, 25 °C): 27.66, 27.68 ((CH3)3C-A,B); 29.67, 29.70 (d, JC,P = 6.5, SCH2CH2O-A,B); 30.61 (CH2-4′-B); 32.29 (CH2-4′-A); 34.70 (d, JC,P = 133.0, CH2P-A,B); 45.78 (CH2-5′-B); 47.18 (CH2-5′-A); 47.51 ((CH3)3C-A,B); 51.62 (CH2-2′-A); 52.62 (CH2-2′-B); 54.47 (CH-3′-A); 55.51 (CH-3′-B); 66.40, 66.48, 66.51 (d, JC,P = 6.4, SCH2CH2O-A,B); 117.95, 117.98 (C-5-A,B); 137.69, 137.88 (CH-8-A,B); 153.08 (C-4-A,B); 155.14 (C-2-A,B); 159.37 (C-6-A,B); 165.41, 165.55 (d, JC,P = 5.7, NCO-A,B); 207.05 (SCO-A,B). 31P 1H NMR (202.3 MHz, CD3OD, 25 °C): 23.42, 23.49.
    HRMS (ESI–) for C25H39N6O7PNa (M + Na)+: calcd, 653.19515; found, 653.19519. This compound is >95% pure as assessed by LC/MS.

    Synthesis of N4-(6-Methoxyquinolin-8-yl)pentane-1,4-diamine (Primaquine) Diamide Prodrug of Diisopropyl (S)-((2-(Guanin-9-yl)pyrrolidine-1-yl)-2-oxoethyl)phosphonate (VI-D)

    Bromotrimethylsilane (0.3 mL, 2.2 mmol) was added to the solution of diisopropyl (S)-((2-(guanin-9-yl)pyrrolidine-1-yl)-2-oxoethyl)phosphonate (synthesized according to a published procedure(22)) (0.19 g, 0.44 mmol) in pyridine (5 mL) at rt under an argon atmosphere and the reaction mixture was stirred overnight. This reaction mixture was concentrated in vacuo at the exclusion of moisture and dissolved in the same solvent (5 mL). Primaquine-free base (0.57 g, 2.2 g), triphenylphosphine (0.92 g, 3.52 mmol), DIPEA (0.3 mL, 1.76 mmol), and aldrithiol (0.77 g, 3.52 mmol) were added to the solution and the reaction mixture was stirred under an argon atmosphere at rt for 2 days. This reaction mixture was concentrated in vacuo and the desired product was obtained by column chromatography on silica gel using a linear gradient of methanol in chloroform, followed by preparative reversed-phase HPLC using a linear gradient of methanol in water in 80% yield (mg, mmol). ∼1:1 mixture of amidic rotamers (each of them is a mixture of 4 diastereoisomers) = 8 isomers. 1H NMR (500.0 MHz, CD3OD): 1.19–1.29 (m, 48H, CH3CH(NH)CH2CH2CH2N); 1.48–1.72 (m, 64H, CH3CH(NH)CH2CH2CH2N); 2.24–2.43 (m, 16H, H-4′); 2.79–2.94 (m, 48H, CH2P, CH3CH(NH)CH2CH2CH2N); 3.47–3.54 (m, 4H, H-5′); 3.54–3.72 (m, 24H, H-5′, CH3CH(NH)CH2CH2CH2N); 3.73–3.82 (m, 8H, H-2′,5′); 3.820, 3.826, 3.827, 3.831, 3.835, 3.837, 3.845 (7 × s, 48H, CH3O); 3.86–3.95, 4.05–4.13 (2m, 12H, H-2′); 4.88–4.95 (m, 8H, H-3′, overlapped with water signal); 6.24–6.31 (m, 16H, H-7-quin); 6.36–6.44 (m, 16H, H-5-quin); 7.27–7.35 (m, 16H, H-3-quin); 7.69, 7.743, 7.749, 7.752, 7.760 (5 × s, 8H, H-8); 7.93–8.02 (m, 16H, H-4-quin); 8.42–8.49 (m, 16H, H-2-quin).
    13C NMR (125.7 MHz, CD3OD): 20.83, 20.84 (CH3CH(NH)CH2CH2CH2N); 29.63, 29.67 (CH3CH(NH)CH2CH2CH2N); 30.56, 32.12 (CH2-4′); 34.72, 34.74, 34.76, 34.89 (CH3CH(NH)CH2CH2CH2N); 37.23, 37.71 (2 × d, JC,P = 100.3, CH2P); 40.91–41.29 (m, CH3CH(NH)CH2CH2CH2N); 45.49, 47.10, 47.12 (CH2-5′); 48.46 (CH3CH(NH)CH2CH2CH2N); 51.39, 51.42, 52.34, 52.36, 52.39, 52.41 (CH2-2′); 54.24, 55.29 (CH-3′); 55.63 (CH3O); 92.89, 92.95 (CH-5-quin); 98.29, 98.31, 98.36 (CH-7-quin); 117.92, 117.95 (C-5); 122.92, 122.94 (CH-3-quin); 131.55, 131.56, 131.57 (C-4a-quin); 136.29, 136.30, 136.31, 136.33 (CH-4-quin); 136.43, 136.44, 136.45 (C-8a-quin); 137.59, 137.70, 137.72, 137.75, 137.77 (CH-8); 145.295, 145.300, 145.317, 145.325 (CH-2-quin); 146.14, 146.16 (C-8-quin); 152.988, 152.994, 153.037, 153.044 (C-4); 155.10 (C-2); 159.38, 159.39 (C-6); 160.95, 160.96, 160.97, 160.98 (C-6-quin); 167.65–167.86 (m, COCH2P). 31P 1H NMR (202.4 MHz, CD3OD): 26.07; 26.12; 26.13; 26.15; 26.21; 26.22; 26.25. IR νmax: (CHCl3) 3360 (w, br), 2928 (m), 2860 (m, w), 2834 (sh, w), 1693 (s, ws), 1654 (sh, m), 1640 (sh, s), 1632 (sh, s), 1618 (vs), 1577 (s), 1521 (vs), 1444 (sh, m), 1389 (s), 1374 (sh), 1255 (m), 1238 (m), 1198 (s), 1166 (s), 1121 (m), 1091 (m, w), 1052 (m, w), 1032 (w), 888 (w), 821 (m), 847 (m), 641 (w). HR-ESI C41H54O5N12P (M + H)+: calcd, 825.40723; found, 825.40794. This compound is >95% pure as assessed by LC/MS.

    1. 1
      Marshall, B.; Warren, J. R. Unidentified curved bacilli in the stomach of patients with gastritis and peptic ulceration. Lancet 1984, 323, 1311– 1315,  DOI: 10.1016/s0140-6736(84)91816-6
      [Crossref], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
    2. 2
      Hooi, J. K. Y.; Lai, W. Y.; Ng, W. K.; Suen, M. M. Y.; Underwood, F. E.; Tanyingoh, D.; Malfertheiner, P.; Graham, D. Y.; Wong, V. W. S.; Wu, J. C. Y.; Chan, F. K. L.; Sung, J. J. Y.; Kaplan, G. G.; Ng, S. C. Global prevalence of Helicobacter pylori infection: Systematic review and meta-analysis. Gastroenterology 2017, 153, 420– 429,  DOI: 10.1053/j.gastro.2017.04.022
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      Global Prevalence of Helicobacter pylori Infection: Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
      Hooi James K Y; Lai Wan Ying; Suen Michael M Y; Wong Vincent W S; Wu Justin C Y; Chan Francis K L; Sung Joseph J Y; Ng Wee Khoon; Underwood Fox E; Tanyingoh Divine; Malfertheiner Peter; Graham David Y; Kaplan Gilaad G; Ng Siew C
      Gastroenterology (2017), 153 (2), 420-429 ISSN:.
      BACKGROUND & AIMS: The epidemiology of Helicobacter pylori infection has changed with improvements in sanitation and methods of eradication. We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis to evaluate changes in the global prevalence of H pylori infection. METHODS: We performed a systematic search of the MEDLINE and EMBASE databases for studies of the prevalence of H pylori infection published from January 1, 1970 through January 1, 2016. We analyzed data based on United Nations geoscheme regions and individual countries. We used a random effects model to calculate pooled prevalence estimates with 95% confidence intervals (CIs), weighted by study size. We extrapolated 2015 prevalence estimates to obtain the estimated number of individuals with H pylori infection. RESULTS: Among 14,006 reports screened, we identified 263 full-text articles on the prevalence of H pylori infection; 184 were included in the final analysis, comprising data from 62 countries. Africa had the highest pooled prevalence of H pylori infection (70.1%; 95% CI, 62.6-77.7), whereas Oceania had the lowest prevalence (24.4%; 95% CI, 18.5-30.4). Among individual countries, the prevalence of H pylori infection varied from as low as 18.9% in Switzerland (95% CI, 13.1-24.7) to 87.7% in Nigeria (95% CI, 83.1-92.2). Based on regional prevalence estimates, there were approximately 4.4 billion individuals with H pylori infection worldwide in 2015. CONCLUSIONS: In a systematic review and meta-analysis to assess the prevalence of H pylori infection worldwide, we observed large amounts of variation among regions-more than half the world's population is infected. These data can be used in development of customized strategies for the global eradication.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC1crisFaktA%253D%253D&md5=612061e322f559cdbe6c3a5c86fa0b15
    3. 3
      Hunt, R. H.; Xiao, S. D.; Megraud, F.; Leon-Barua, R.; Bazzoli, F.; van der Merwe, S.; Vaz Coelho, L. G.; Fock, M.; Fedail, S.; Cohen, H.; Malfertheiner, P.; Vakil, N.; Hamid, S.; Goh, K. L.; Wong, B. C.; Krabshuis, J.; Le Mair, A.; World Gastroenterology Organization Helicobacter pylori in developing countries. World gastroenterology organisation global guideline. J. Gastrointest. Liver Dis. 2011, 20, 299– 304
      [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      Helicobacter pylori in developing countries. World Gastroenterology Organisation Global Guideline
      Hunt R H; Xiao S D; Megraud F; Leon-Barua R; Bazzoli F; van der Merwe S; Vaz Coelho L G; Fock M; Fedail S; Cohen H; Malfertheiner P; Vakil N; Hamid S; Goh K L; Wong B C Y; Krabshuis J; Le Mair A
      Journal of gastrointestinal and liver diseases : JGLD (2011), 20 (3), 299-304 ISSN:.
